project: Lisa - Multi-Discipline Creative Orchestration Plugin for Claude Code
description: A Claude Code plugin that brings autonomous orchestration to marketing, PR, and branding teams, using the Ralph Wiggum Stop hook pattern. Lisa helps creative professionals automate campaign deliverables with quality gates, institutional memory, and discipline-appropriate language.

userStories.title: Plugin structure and metadata
userStories.description: As a developer, I need the basic Lisa plugin structure with proper metadata
acceptanceCriteria: Create .claude/plugins/lisa/ directory structure
Create .claude-plugin/plugin.json with name='lisa', version='1.0.0', description, author
Create README.md with overview, quick start, installation instructions
Directory structure matches Ralph Wiggum pattern: commands/, hooks/, scripts/, skills/, schemas/, examples/
All directories created and documented in README
Description mentions support for marketing, PR, and branding disciplines
userStories.notes: Foundation for all other user stories

userStories.title: Campaign brief JSON schema
userStories.description: As a creative professional, I need a structured format to define campaign deliverables across marketing, PR, and branding
acceptanceCriteria: Create schemas/campaign-brief.schema.json with JSON schema
Schema includes: campaign name, description, campaignType enum ('marketing' | 'pr' | 'branding'), deliverables array
Each deliverable has: id, type, title, description, acceptanceCriteria, priority, approved (boolean), targetKeyword, dependencies
Deliverable types enum includes Marketing types: email-sequence, landing-page-copy, social-posts, ad-copy, blog-article, newsletter, case-study, webinar-script
Deliverable types enum includes PR types: press-release, media-pitch, press-kit, crisis-communication, talking-points, media-advisory, op-ed, qa-document, fact-sheet
Deliverable types enum includes Branding types: brand-guidelines, brand-positioning, voice-tone-guide, messaging-framework, tagline, brand-story
Schema validates with standard JSON schema validator
Include examples in schema description fields for each discipline
userStories.notes: Core data structure that drives Lisa's orchestration across all disciplines

userStories.title: Stop hook implementation
userStories.description: As a developer, I need the Stop hook that implements Lisa's iterative loop
acceptanceCriteria: Create hooks/stop-hook.sh (executable, #!/bin/bash)
Reads .claude/lisa-campaign.local.md state file
Extracts YAML frontmatter: iteration, max_iterations, completion_promise, campaign_name, campaign_type
Validates numeric fields before arithmetic operations
Checks if max_iterations reached → exit 0 if yes
Reads transcript from stdin JSON, extracts last assistant message
Checks for <promise>COMPLETION_TEXT</promise> using exact string matching
If complete → delete state file, exit 0
If incomplete → increment iteration, re-inject prompt, output JSON with decision='block'
Atomic state file updates using temp file pattern
Include discipline-appropriate system messages (emojis, progress indicators)
System message adapts based on campaign_type (marketing/PR/branding terminology)
userStories.notes: Core orchestration logic - critical component, discipline-agnostic

userStories.title: Context directory and file structure
userStories.description: As a Lisa user, I need a place to store company-specific context that persists across campaigns and projects
acceptanceCriteria: Create context/ directory at plugin root: ~/.claude/plugins/marketplaces/local/plugins/lisa/context/
Create schema for company-profile.json with fields: companyName, industry, foundedYear, teamSize, mission, valuePropositions, targetAudience, keyProducts, metrics, boilerplate

Add .gitignore entry for context/ (user-specific, not committed)

style-preferences.json includes readabilityThresholds section with per-deliverable-type thresholds
Readability threshold fallback chain: (1) deliverable acceptanceCriteria override, (2) style-preferences.json user defaults, (3) built-in system defaults from testing
Built-in defaults based on testing all 23 deliverable types: visual-identity-brief=50, thought-leadership=55, crisis-response=70, etc.
Users can override specific types in style-preferences.json without configuring all 23
Campaign brief acceptanceCriteria should use semantic language (Readable by executives) with numeric overrides only for special cases
userStories.notes: Foundation for personalized content. Context lives at plugin level (shared across projects), not project level. User can version control by symlinking context/ to their own repo. Readability thresholds configured here with smart fallback: acceptanceCriteria override → style-preferences.json → built-in defaults from testing. Solves IMPROVE-001.

acceptanceCriteria: During campaign, user can provide feedback: I wouldn not say it like that or This worked really well
Lisa updates lisa-memory-contextual.json with the correction or success pattern
Memory entry includes: deliverable type, what was learned, when to apply it, example
Memory entries tagged by category: voice, formatting, content-type-specific, quality-threshold
Next deliverable of same type applies learned pattern automatically
Memory includes whenToUse field so Lisa knows when to apply each learning
User can view memory: /lisa:show-memory command lists learned patterns
User can edit memory: lisa-memory-contextual.json is human-readable JSON
Memory persists across campaigns and projects
Over time, fewer corrections needed as Lisa learns user preferences
userStories.notes: This is the wow factor - Lisa gets smarter about your company with each campaign. Mirrors how real coordinators learn team preferences.

userStories.title: Company setup documentation and examples
userStories.description: As a new Lisa user, I need clear instructions on how to set up Lisa for my company without technical knowledge
acceptanceCriteria: README section: Setting Up Lisa for Your Company
Step-by-step: Run /lisa:setup-company skill
Examples of what to provide: brand guide, company one-pager, style guide
Show sample company-profile.json with annotations
Show sample brand-voice.json with examples from different industries
Explain what each context file does in plain language
Troubleshooting: My content still feels generic (check if context loaded)
How to update context as company evolves
How to verify Lisa is using your context (run test campaign)
Video walkthrough or screenshots for setup process
userStories.notes: User education is critical. These are marketers/PR pros, not developers. Setup must feel accessible and confidence-building.

Agent prompts adapt correctly to marketing, PR, and branding contexts
Extensibility points documented for future enhancements and additional disciplines

notes: All 28 user stories systematically tested using Ralph Wiggum loop
Quality check scripts validated with real test content

deliverableTypeTesting.description: Testing all 23 deliverable types across 3 disciplines to verify end-to-end functionality

email-sequence.notes: Tested successfully. Created 2-email welcome sequence (98 & 122 words). Passed brand compliance and readability (95.1). Very easy to read at 5th grade level.

landing-page-copy.notes: Tested successfully. Created landing page with hero, 2 features, CTAs. Passed brand compliance, readability (70.8), and SEO check (4.18% keyword density for analytics dashboard).

social-posts.notes: Tested in lisa-test-campaign.json - passed all quality gates

ad-copy.notes: Tested successfully. Created Google search ad with headline (20 chars) and description (67 chars) within limits. Passed brand compliance and readability (90.3) after simplifying supporting text.

blog-article.notes: Tested successfully. Created 547-word blog article with H2/H3 structure. Passed brand compliance, readability (80.8), and SEO (2.12% keyword density with meta description).

newsletter.notes: Tested successfully. Created 310-word newsletter with 3 sections (New Features, What's Next, Try Features). Passed brand compliance and readability (97.3 - 1st grade level). Short sentences, conversational tone, clear headers.

case-study.notes: Tested successfully. Created 615-word case study with Problem-Solution-Results structure, 4 customer quotes, 6 specific metrics. Passed brand compliance and readability (70.0 - 8th grade level). Strong balance of storytelling and data.

webinar-script.notes: Tested successfully. Created 1,087-word webinar script for 30-min format with intro, demo, Q&A, outro. Includes 6 time markers and 11 speaker notes. Passed brand compliance and readability (88.4 - 6th grade level). Excellent conversational flow for live delivery.

press-release.notes: Tested successfully. Created 542-word press release with AP Style formatting, inverted pyramid structure, executive quote, customer proof point, boilerplate, media contact. Passed brand compliance and readability (60.9 - 8th grade level). Proper formal tone for news wire distribution.

media-pitch.notes: Tested successfully. Created 234-word media pitch with strong subject line (10,000 teams hook), newsworthy opening, key details, multiple CTAs. Passed brand compliance and readability (74.8 - 7th grade level). Excellent structure for busy journalists.

media-kit.notes: Tested successfully. Created 474-word media kit with company overview, key facts, executive bios, media contact, product info. Required 1 revision - first attempt scored 48.4 readability, second attempt 70.5. Passed brand compliance. Important learning: even reference docs need simple language.

executive-bio.notes: Tested successfully. Created 212-word CEO biography in third person with current role, career highlights (Google, 6 years), education (Stanford PhD), achievements (10,000 teams in 90 days, Forbes 30 Under 30), and personal details. Passed brand compliance and readability (70.1 - 7th grade level).

thought-leadership.notes: Tested successfully. Created 732-word thought leadership article with clear POV (data democratization), industry insights, forward-looking vision, strong executive voice. Passed brand compliance and readability (82.2 - 6th grade level). Declarative statements and personal experience make bold ideas accessible.

crisis-response.notes: Tested successfully. Created 298-word crisis response for service outage with acknowledgment, empathy, explanation, resolution timeline (10:15 AM - 1:15 PM), prevention steps with deadline (Jan 15). Passed brand compliance and readability (79.9 - 7th grade level). Clear, transparent, accountable tone.

byline-article.notes: Tested successfully. Created 796-word byline article with strong opening hook (vulnerability), 4 H2 sections, personal anecdotes (Google, 12-person team), actionable steps in each section, first-person author voice. Passed brand compliance and readability (73.4 - 7th grade level). Perfect blend of storytelling and practical advice.

media-alert.notes: Tested successfully. Created 161-word media alert with Who/What/When/Where format, event details, media opportunity (CEO interview), RSVP deadline and contact. Required 1 revision - first attempt scored 49.6 readability, second attempt 71.1. Passed brand compliance. Standard format makes it scannable.

spokesperson-prep.notes: Tested successfully. Created 481-word spokesperson prep with 5 key messages, 5 sound bites, 7 key statistics, 5 Q&As, topics to avoid, background reminders. Passed brand compliance and readability (70.9 - 7th grade level). Comprehensive interview prep with exact phrases and clear boundaries.

brand-positioning.notes: Tested successfully. Created 497-word brand positioning with target audience, competitive landscape, unique value prop, reason to believe, brand promise. Required 1 revision - first attempt scored 44.3 readability, second attempt 75.3. Passed brand compliance. Strategic documents need simple language too.

messaging-framework.notes: Tested successfully. Created 577-word messaging framework with core message, 4 pillars (Simple, Fast, Business-Focused, Proven Growth), supporting points, audience variations, proof points. Required 1 revision - first attempt scored 51.6 readability, second attempt 60.1. Passed brand compliance. Split compound bullet points into separate items to improve readability.

value-proposition.notes: Tested successfully. Created 327-word value proposition with one-sentence statement, 5 key benefits, competitor differentiation, pain points section, and before/after transformation. No revision needed - scored 73.5 readability on first attempt. Passed brand compliance. First branding deliverable to pass without revision.

brand-voice-guide.notes: Tested successfully. Created 731-word brand voice guide with 5 voice attributes (Clear, Confident, Practical, Friendly, Honest), tone variations for 4 contexts, do/don't examples for each attribute, writing guidelines, and sample phrases. Required 1 fix - brand check flagged 'revolutionize' in a Don't example. Scored 71.1 readability after fix. Important learning: prohibited terms can't appear even in negative examples.

visual-identity-brief.notes: Tested successfully. Created 555+ word visual identity brief with brand personality, visual direction, color palette, type choices, imagery style, competitor comparison. Required 3 major revisions - started at 28.2 readability (lowest score yet), revised to 49.5, then 58.3, finally 66.7. Design vocabulary is naturally technical. Key breakthrough: replacing category names (Enterprise→Big tools, Consumer→Simple tools, Typography→Type, Deliverables→Work) instead of just shortening sentences.

tagline-concepts.notes: Tested successfully. Created 413-word tagline concepts document with 8 tagline options (each 3-5 words), rationale for each, strategic themes summary. No revision needed - scored 60.9 readability on first attempt. Second branding deliverable to pass without revision (after value-proposition). Natural format enforces simplicity.

improvements.title: Configurable readability thresholds per content type
improvements.description: Current readability threshold of 60 for all content creates choppy, robotic prose for content that should flow naturally (thought leadership, marketing copy, storytelling). Testing all 23 deliverable types revealed systematic patterns showing which content types naturally achieve readability and which require forced simplification.
improvements.problem: Ultra-short sentences (2-6 words) hit readability targets but sacrifice conversational flow and sophisticated voice. Press releases should be formal/scannable. Thought leadership should allow more nuanced expression. Crisis response needs maximum clarity. Strategic branding documents use complex concepts that resist simplification.
improvements.proposedSolution: Allow readability thresholds to vary by content type, either in deliverable acceptanceCriteria or in global quality-gates config. Consider adding conversational-flow check alongside readability.

testingEvidence.summary: Tested all 23 deliverable types (8 Marketing, 9 PR, 6 Branding). Clear patterns emerged showing natural readability levels and revision effort required.

requiredMajorRevision.notes: Design vocabulary is inherently technical - worst offender

keyInsights: Branding deliverables consistently struggle (4 of 6 required revision)
Marketing deliverables mostly pass first attempt (6 of 8 passed)
PR deliverables split evenly (some need formality, some need clarity)
Visual identity brief scored 28.2 initially - required replacing entire vocabulary (enterprise→big tools, professional→business like)
Strategic documents (positioning, messaging) use complex concepts that become choppy when oversimplified
Action-oriented content (emails, crisis response) naturally achieves high readability

rationale.marketing: Generally conversational and action-oriented. Higher thresholds (65-70) for direct-response content (emails, ads, social). Lower (58-60) for narrative content (case studies, blogs).
rationale.pr: Wide range. Crisis communications need maximum clarity (70). Thought leadership and bylines can be sophisticated (55). Press releases balance formality with scannability (60).
rationale.branding: Strategic documents use complex concepts. Positioning and messaging frameworks need room for nuance (55-58). Visual identity briefs use design vocabulary (50). Simple formats like taglines naturally achieve high scores (65).

examples.currentApproach: All content must score 60+ (leads to choppy sentences)
examples.proposedApproach: Thresholds vary by content type and purpose

improvements.userFeedback: Even when writing a press release, it's probably going to be more formal than a blog post. Readability is important but you don't want sentences so choppy they don't read conversationally when they need to.
improvements.implementationNotes: Could be part of style-preferences.json in context system (US-029). Users configure readability preferences per content type. Default thresholds based on testing data above. Allow override in campaign brief acceptanceCriteria.
